info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 16 at 10:54AM EST by NWS Chicago
info.description: ...Heavy Rainfall and Shifting River Ice Remain Possible... Warmer temperatures today will be followed by widespread rainfall this evening into tomorrow, some of which may be heavy in localized areas. A combination of snow melt and rainfall could lead to significant river rises in some areas, including water levels near flood stage. Isolated break-up ice jams may also occur. This flood potential exists from today through the weekend. Confidence in heavy rainfall and flooding has decreased slightly since previous outlooks. Snow cover has begun quickly melting over the last 12 hours and is expected to be almost entirely melted by tomorrow morning. Soil frost depths range from 6 to 12 inches across the outlook area, which may be enough to reduce infiltration from rainfall and snow melt. Soil moisture across the area is near average, which will not significantly impact flood risk. Overall, conditions are generally leading to an increased rate of runoff due to rainfall. River forecasts based upon 48 hours of future rainfall indicate significant river rises and near flood stage conditions at multiple locations along the Iroquois, Kankakee, and Illinois rivers and their tributaries. River rises from a combination of ongoing snow melt and future rainfall are likely to break up ice cover in some areas, which may lead to isolated break-up ice jams. Ice jams can develop quickly and lead to rapid water level fluctuations with little or no notice. This outlook means that elevated water levels and potential impacts are possible, but not yet certain. Persons should closely monitor the latest forecasts and statements, including possible flood watches and warnings. No additional outlooks are expected for this event.
